Graphical abstract The deep-chlorination problem of catalyst in HCl oxidation was solved on a robust copper catalyst due to the significantly enhanced desorption of Cl2 thereon. Offering a substantial method to convert HCl to Cl2 over CuCl2/pumice, Deacon process is of great importance in chemical industry. In the process, the difficulty of Cl2 formation/desorption and catalyst re-oxidation have been unanimously recognized as the origin of the instability of CuO-based catalysts. In this work, the stability of the CuO/Al2O3 catalyst was significantly improved by adding Co. The fabricated CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst showed unprecedented stability with HCl conversion (x HCl) above 80%, lasting for at least 1000 h. The X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectra, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) characterizations suggested that the addition of Co greatly enhanced the dispersion of CuO on Al2O3 and hindered the reduction of CuO due to their strong interaction. The results of reaction kinetics suggested that the lattice oxygen participated in the reaction and the reaction order on oxygen was estimated to be 0.15, suggesting that the catalyst obeyed the Mars-van Krevelen (M-K) mechanism, while only small amount of oxygen was required to maintain the activity of catalysts compared to CuO/Al2O3. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations proved that the CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 ternary system was more stable than CuO/Al2O3 binary system and easier to be oxidized by O2, which greatly reduced the difficulty of Cl2 associative desorption. Keywords HCl oxidation Cl2 desorption CuO-based catalyst Cobalt Mars-van Krevelen mechanism 1 Introduction In heterogeneous catalytic reactions, such as ammonia synthesis [1–3], hydrogen production by methane reforming [4], reduction of nitro compounds to amines [5], selective catalytic reduction (SCR) [6–9], facilitating the rate-controlling step is crucial to increase the overall reaction rate. The presence of the rate-controlling step can not only reduce the overall reaction rate but also significantly change the phase of catalyst that leads to deactivation. The CuO-based catalyst in Deacon process is one case. First proposed in 1868, Deacon process offered a substantial manner to catalytically convert HCl to Cl2 over CuCl2/pumice and the research on CuO-based catalysts lasted for nearly 150 years [10]. Macroscopically, HCl oxidation can be roughly considered as a dual-step redox reaction, which involves (i) HCl adsorption with H2O formation accompanied by chlorination of the catalyst, and (ii) Cl2 desorption accompanied by re-oxidation of the catalyst [11]. Temporal analysis of products on copper catalyst showed that fresh CuO followed M-K mechanism with lattice oxygen involved in the redox cycle [12]. Previous studies revealed that HCl was ready to adsorb on CuO with low activation energy, forming the intermediates like CuOCl or Cu(OH)OCl in the first step, making the CuO bulk catalyst deeply chlorinated. In the second step, however, the re-oxidation of the intermediates to CuO by oxygen with Cl2 formation and desorption is quite difficult. Pérez-Ramírez et al. reported that the adsorption of Cl2 in CuO was even stronger than HCl, leading to the difficulty of Cl2 desorption and therefore the deactivation of CuO [12]. Therefore, enhancing Cl2 desorption and O2 adsorption on CuO based catalysts are the keys to improve stability. Meanwhile, to maintain the activity of catalyst, the adsorption energy of HCl should not be remarkable decreased. It is worth noting that the constituent unit of CuO and the intermediates can be roughly regarded as Cu-O-Cu and Cu–Cl–Cu, respectively, and the catalytic processes can be thought of as cycles of chlorination and re-oxidation. If we design a unit of asymmetric metal elements, such as Cu–O–M, the shift of the electron would essentially occur within the unit [13–16]. As a result, the presence of M metal could probably facilitate O2 adsorption of oxygen and promote the re-oxidation of Cu–Cl–M, and thus accelerating the desorption of Cl2. To improve the stability of the catalyst, Pérez-Ramírez et al. reported some delafossite-based copper catalysts, i.e. CuAlO2, CuCrO2, CuGaO2, CuFeO2 and CuMnO2, for HCl oxidation [17,18]. The authors found that CuCrO2 followed Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism with excellent stability, which may be attributed to the modulating effect of Cr for Cu-based catalysts. The satisfactory stability, however, was achieved at the expense of catalytic activity, which was probably caused by the weakened HCl adsorption. As for other delafossite-based copper catalysts, the desorption of Cl2 was not facilitated, which resulted in obvious bulk phase transition in the reaction process. It is noteworthy that even these deactivated delafossite-based copper catalysts behaved differently. For example, CuAlO2 was unstable in the reaction atmosphere, but spinel CuAl2O4 generated from CuAlO2 was stable; however, neither CuMnO2 nor spinel CuMn2O4 generated from it was unstable in the reaction atmosphere. These results indicate that both the type of hetero atom and the formed crystal type could affect the performance and mechanism of the catalysts. Besides, it has been reported that rare earth metals such as La, Ce, Sm promote the CuO-based catalysts, which exhibited significantly improved stability [19–21]. The improved stability was generally ascribed to the highly dispersed copper oxide or surface oxygen vacancy (SOV) formed thereon, without considering the reaction kinetics and mechanism. The above analysis of the literature suggests that the understanding of the doping of copper-based catalysts by a second metal and the corresponding reaction mechanism is only the tip of an iceberg. There are still many mysteries worthy of in-depth study. Based on the strategy of enhancing Cl2 desorption and catalyst re-oxidation, herein we constructed Cu–O–M catalytic unit by using Co as the second metal to enhance Cl2 evolution. As expected, the results showed that CuO(12) –CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst not only exhibited the relatively high activity above 80% but also delivered an unprecedented stability for at least 1000 h run. The characterizations revealed that the addition of Co greatly reduced the reducibility of CuO. In addition, DFT calculations indicated the enhanced Cl2 associative desorption in CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalyst without obvious decrease of HCl adsorption. This point could be regarded as the intrinsic reason for the enhanced stability of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The carrier γ-Al2O3 was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. in the pelletized form (diameter = 4 mm) and the BET surface area was determined to be 297.5 m2 g−1. The pelletized carrier was crushed and sieved to get 40–60 mesh components prior to use. γ-Al2O3 was added into the aqueous solution containing a certain stoichiometric proportion of Cu(NO3)2 and Co(NO3)2 (the total loading weight of CuO and CoO x on γ-Al2O3 is 25%). The catalysts were obtained after drying at 110 °C overnight in an oven and calcined at 450 °C in air for 4 h. To investigate the effect of the doping amount of CoO x on the activity of catalysts, the weight ratio of CuO to CoO x were varied at 0:25, 10:15, 12:13, 15:10, 17:8, 19:6, 21:4, 25:0. The obtained samples were denoted by CoO x /Al2O3, CuO(10) –CoO x (15)/Al2O3, CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3, CuO(15)–CoO x (10)/Al2O3, CuO(17)–CoO x (8)/Al2O3, CuO(19)–CoO x (6)/Al2O3, CuO(21)–CoO x (4)/Al2O3, CuO/Al2O3, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterizations XRD patterns of samples were recorded using a Rigaku D/max 2550 VB diffractometer with filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) from a generator operating at 40 kV and 450 mA. The project-augmented wave (PAW) method was used to represent the core-valence interaction [25,26]. For the calculations of total energy, a cut-off energy of 400 eV was set for plane-wave basis sets to expand the valence electronic states, and the converging criteria of the force on each relaxed atom below 0.05 eV/Å was used for structural optimizations. The formation energy (E F) of a certain surface can be calculated as (taking CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 as an example): E F (CuO–CoO x /Al2O3) = E(CuO–CoO x /Al2O3) – E(CuO) – E(CoO x ) – E(Al2O3) where E(X) stands for the total energy of X; the total energy of CuO and CoO x are referred to their bulk materials. To obtain the free energy of species, the standard formulas of statistical mechanics were used to calculate the zero point energy (ZPE), thermal energy, and entropy derived from partition functions (see section SI-2 in the Supporting Information for detailed equations) [8,27]. Furthermore, ab initio thermodynamic [28,29] was employed to evaluate the surface energy γ at experimental conditions. G sur stands for the free energy of the surfaces and A is the area of the surface in the unit cell. In this study, bulk CoO and CuO were used for reference energy, and G sur was calculated directly from DFT total energy since the vibrational contribution to the surface free energy is neglectable (less than 3% at 500 K) [30,31]. It should be noted that the ab initio thermodynamics evaluates the stability at equilibrium state, which does not take the kinetic factor into account. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance To select the optimal ratio of CuO to CoO x and the optimal reaction temperature for HCl oxidation, the catalytic activities of all samples at different temperatures were investigated (Fig. 1 and Table 1 ). When the reaction temperature is below 350 °C, all catalysts exhibit a low x HCl of less than 40%, while x HCl increases sharply before reaching a platform (or decrease slightly) with the increase of temperature above 350 °C. Owing to that HCl oxidation is an equilibrium-limited reaction, the highest x HCl of 80% is obtained on CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at 390 °C. Limited by equilibrium conversion rate [32], the x HCl of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst does not increase any more when the reaction temperature exceeds 390 °C. Since CoO x /Al2O3 is not active for HCl oxidation (Fig. S1), the STY of Cl2 on all samples is compared based on the catalyst weight and the CuO weight contained in the catalyst, respectively (Table 1). It is clear that CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst shows both the highest STY of Cl2 of 2.17 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 and 4.52 gCl2 gCuO −1 h−1. The apparent activation energies (E a) of all samples were estimated by plotting lnx HCl vs. 1/T as shown in Fig. 2 . Ranging between 88 and 110 kJ/mol, the E a of Cu–CoO x /Al2O3 series catalysts are lower than that of CuMnO2 (140 kJ/mol) and close to that of CuCrO2 and CuAlO2 (90 kJ/mol) [18]. Among them, CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst presents the lowest E a of 88.3 kJ/mol. The long-term stability of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 . The CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst shows unprecedented stability for at least 1000 h with x HCl of 80%. Compared with other CuO-based catalysts as shown in Table 2 , the x HCl value of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 is quite close to that with addition of rare earth metals including Ce, La and Sm [19–21]. Considering the STY value, CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 is in the medium level. As for stability, to date, CuO(12)–CeO2(13)/Y was reported to maintain its initial activity for 1200 h. Besides, CuKSm25 and CuCrO2–CeO2 catalysts were reported to keep active for 120 h and 200 h, respectively. It was found that the color of fresh and used catalysts changed from black to green for CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 after 1000 h run. From the color change, we can refer that chlorination occurred for CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst. However, whether the chlorination occurs on the bulk (like traditional CuO catalyst) or on the surface (like RuO2 catalyst) is still uncertain, which will be revealed below. 3.2 Characterizations The bulk crystalline structures of γ-Al2O3, CuO/Al2O3, CoO x /Al2O3 and CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 were characterized by XRD as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The characteristic peaks at 2θ of 35.4° and 38.7° in CuO/Al2O3 are identified as tenorite phase CuO [12]. The peaks at 18.9°, 31.2°, 36.9°, 38.4°, 44.8°, 55.6°, 59.2° and 65.1° in CoO x /Al2O3 are attributed to be (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) planes of spinel phase Co3O4 [33]. As for CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3, the characteristic peaks of CuO disappear completely, suggesting the distinct effect of Co on CuO dispersion. It is noteworthy that the characteristic peak of the (311) plane of Co3O4 shifts slightly from 36.98° to 36.82° (displayed at the top left corner in Fig. 4(a)). This is probably attributed to the entrance of Cu atoms into the lattice of Co3O4, which leads to the lattice expansion of Co3O4, and the (311) spacing of Co3O4 becomes broadened from 2.428 Å to 2.439 Å. Besides, Raman spectroscopy was adopted here to investigate the surface dispersion of metal oxides on CuO/Al2O3, CoO x /Al2O3 and CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalysts as shown in Fig. 4(b). As for CuO/Al2O3, there are three peaks appearing at 292, 341 and 626 cm−1 attributed to CuO [34]. For CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst, the peaks of CuO vanish and the peaks of Co3O4 become weakened in the meantime, indicating that the surface CuO species have also been well dispersed by CoO x , which is in accordance with the results of XRD. Therefore, the reducibility of all samples was investigated by H2-TPR experiment as shown in Fig. 6 . The two peaks appearing at 175 °C (α peak) and 245 °C (β peak) for CuO/Al2O3 belong to the reduction of dispersed (or amorphous) CuO and bulk (or crystalline) CuO, respectively, according to reference [35]. Similarly, as for CoO x /Al2O3, the peak at 376 °C is probably attributed to the dispersed Co3O4, and the peak at 597 °C could be attributed to the crystalline Co3O4 [36]. When Co was introduced to CuO/Al2O3, the wide peak can be carefully deconvoluted into three peaks at 193, 263, and 334 °C, denoted by α, β and γ, respectively. The α and β peaks of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 are likely assigned to the dispersed CuO and crystalline CuO, respectively. However, the position of two peaks shift to a higher temperature and the ratio of H2 consumption of α to β peak increases compared to that of CuO/Al2O3, suggesting the obviously increased amount of dispersed CuO. The γ peak of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4, yet the temperature of γ peak is lower than that of Co3O4/Al2O3, probably caused by the influence of CuO on Co3O4. Therefore, we suggest that the mutual dispersion and strong interaction between CuO and Co3O4 result in the higher reduction temperature of CuO and lower reduction temperature of Co3O4. 3.3 Kinetic test In order to understand the high activity and stability of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst, we further investigated the kinetics and phase transition under different reaction atmosphere. The effect of feed O2/HCl ratio on the performance of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 7 (a). It is observed that x HCl ascend with the increase of the feed O2/HCl ratio, indicating that a higher oxygen partial pressure is favorable to the performance for catalysts. In addition, the activity almost reaches a plateau when the feed O2/HCl ratio exceeds 3. By using a power equation to fit the curve, the reaction order on O2 of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst was estimated to be 0.15, which is lower than the value of 0.5 of delafossite CuCrO2 catalyst reported in the reference [18]. This indicates that CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 is easier to be re-oxidized than delafossite CuCrO2. In addition, it is noted that the x HCl of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 drops from 80% to 32%, when O2 is switched off in Fig. 7(b). And here we can give an answer to the previous question about where the chlorination occurred during 1000 h run, in the bulk or on the surface of catalyst. Based on Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, the chlorination exactly occurred in the bulk of CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst. To explore the possible phase transition of CuO/Al2O3, CoO x /γ-Al2O3 and CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalysts during the reaction. The XRD patterns of fresh and used three catalysts after 5 h run are shown in Fig. 8 . It is observed in Fig. 8(a) that the significant bulk phase transition from CuO to Cu2(OH)3Cl occurs for CuO/Al2O3 after 5 h run. As for the used CoO x /Al2O3, the obvious phase transition from Co3O4 to CoCl2 2H2O also occurs. Comparatively, no obvious phase transition is observed for the used CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at O2/HCl = 2 and even lower O2/HCl = 0.5 in Fig. 8(b). Only when the feed O2/HCl ratio decreases to zero can the weak peaks of Cu2(OH)3Cl be found for the used catalyst, accompanied by the strong peaks of CoCl2 2H2O. This contrast justifies that the deep chlorination of CuO and Co3O4 under reaction atmosphere is significantly inhibited when they are co-loaded on Al2O3, which leads to significantly improved stability. Correspondingly, less O2 are required to maintain the oxidation state of CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 than that of CuO/Al2O3. Previous studies revealed that Cl atoms was adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy in CuO crystalline and formed strong Cu–Cl–Cu bond, which was not easy to be oxidized [12]. In this paper, the characterization results of XRD (Fig. 4) and H2-TPR (Fig. 6) of fresh catalysts suggest that there is a strong interaction between CuO and Co3O4 in CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalyst. Correspondingly, the CuO species in CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 is more difficult to be reduced than that in CuO/Al2O3, due to the introduction of Co. The XRD results of used catalysts (Fig. 8) also suggest that the presence of Co in the CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalyst greatly inhibited the deep chlorination of catalysts under reaction atmosphere. So here we refer that Cl atoms are possibly adsorbed on the synthetic oxygen vacancy between CuO and Co3O4, and the possible bond of Cu–Cl–Co is easy to be resumed to Cu–O–Co. This assumption will be identified in the following DFT calculations part. 3.4 DFT calculations To further understand the structure of CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalysts and the catalytic mechanism of HCl oxidation, DFT calculations were carried out in this section. The optimized lattice parameters of Al2O3 from DFT calculations are a = 5.61, b = 8.45, c = 8.10 Å, and β = 90.49° shown in Fig. S2(a–c), which are very close to those obtained in the previous computation (a = 5.59, b = 8.42, c = 8.09 Å, and β = 90.58°) [37] and experiments (a = 5.59, b = 8.41, c = 8.07 Å, and β = 90.59°) [38]. The PSO algorithm was implemented by CALYPSO [44,45], which is an effective tool to search for the global minimum of structures for many different systems [46,47]. We can see both are well converged and the best structures are illustrated in Fig. S4 and Fig. 9 . As shown in Fig. S4, the most stable structure for CoOCuO/Al2O3 obtained by CALYPSO is like loading CuO and CoO as a line near the step. It’s reasonable since Al2O3 (110) is a step surface and the introduced Cu and Co atoms tends to gather at the step. CuOCuO/Al2O3 shows similar stable structures. For the multi-nuclear model, as seen in Fig. 9, we can see that the most stable structure (the far left insert) displays a quite orderly arranged Co3O4–CuO layer stretching out of the step, seems like forming a new layer of surface. We then calculated the formation energy (E F) of CuO/Al2O3, CoO/Al2O3 and CoxOy-CuO/Al2O3. Starting from the mono-nuclear sites, as shown in Table S1, the existence of a single CoO or CuO group is not stable enough (E F = −0.04 and −0.02 eV for CuO and CoO, respectively). With two oxide groups, Al2O3 surface becomes much more stable, and loading CoOCuO (−1.59 eV) is more stable than loading CuOCuO (−0.97 eV). The characterizations of XRD, Raman, HRTEM and H2-TPR have proved that the addition of metal Co can promote the high dispersion of copper oxide on Al2O3, and there is a strong interaction between Cu and Co, which is consistent with the results of DFT calculations. Also in Table S1, if we add one more O to the system (oxidation), the E F of OCoOCuO/Al2O3 (−2.28 eV) is lower than that of CoOCuO/Al2O3 (−1.59 eV), while E F of OCuOCuO/Al2O3 (−0.66 eV) is higher than that of CuOCuO/Al2O3 (−0.97 eV). It means that the ternary CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 tends to incorporate more O than the binary CuO/Al2O3 system, and the ternary system itself is more stable than the binary system. To further confirm those speculations, we carried out ab initio thermodynamics calculations to the surface energy γ of clean and loaded Al2O3 (110) surface, the results and analyses of which agree well with above conclusion and are shown in the last column of Table S1 and the following notes. Regarding multi-nuclear sites, Co3O4CuO/Al2O3 is actually the most stable among all with the formation energy of −3.41 eV and the surface energy 2.81 J/m2. Looking at Fig. 9, we can notice that in the most stable structure of Co3O4CuO/Al2O3, the Co and Cu atoms are well ordered stretching out the step of Al2O3 (110) with perfect four coordination, seems like forming a new layer of surface. These results in a low formation energy of Co3O4CuO/Al2O3; however, the catalyst at the real experimental environment is very complicated; we therefore investigated the elementary reactions over all four possible structures listed in Fig. S5 (CoOCuO/Al2O3, CuOCuO/Al2O3, OCoOCuO/Al2O3, Co3O4CuO/Al2O3). Regarding the reaction mechanism, we have carried out a detailed work and concluded that the value of free energy change (ΔG) can be used to indicate the trend of the catalytic activity, and the formation and desorption of the Cl2 could be the ΔG-determining step over spinel ZnCr2O4 [48]. We expect the reaction would go through a similar pattern on the CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 system via a M-K mechanism. We first constructed and calculated ΔG of all elementary reactions that form the catalytic cycle as shown in Fig. 10 and Table 3 . All key structures are shown in Fig. S6. In reaction 1 (HCl adsorption), H always favors adsorbing on the vacancy (noted as HO(vac)) while Cl binds with the metal. In reaction 2, the H* remove with surface O and another H* to form water and oxygen vacancy. After the formation of water, the left vacancy is quickly filled up by the O2 (elementary reaction 4). The ΔG of this reaction is greatly lower than 0 for CuOCuO/Al2O3 and CoOCuO/Al2O3, which is reasonable since the surface tends to adsorb an O to refill the surface and these two structures tend to accommodate more O. It is worth mentioning that the ΔG of this step on CuOCoO (−3.31 eV) is much lower than that of CuOCuO (−1.08 eV), which can be explained by the surface energy analysis we have carried out: CuOCoO favors further oxidation while CuOCuO is relative stable itself. For OCoOCuO and Co3O4, the ΔG rises by 0.47 and 0.02 eV, respectively, since these two structures are already oxygen-rich and hard to accommodate another surface O*. It should also be noted that if the oxygen vacancy is not involved in the reaction (i.e. L−H mechanism), the surface oxygen is produced via the reaction O2 (g) + * → O2*, which is unlikely to occur due to a large increase on the free energy (0.61 and 0.41 eV for CuOCuO and CuOCoO, respectively), which also agrees with our kinetic experiments. After filling up oxygen vacancy, the O left on the surface continues to react with surface H* to form water (reaction 5 and 6), and finally Cl* desorbs as Cl2 (reaction 7). This is the typical process of HCl oxidation over metal oxides; however, instead of O (reaction 4, ΔGO), the surface vacancy can also be filled up by Cl (reaction 3, ΔG Cl), forming a Cu–Cl–Co structure. As shown in Table 3, the ΔG of forming metal-Cl-metal for CuOCuO, CoOCuO, OCoOCuO, and Co3O4CuO are −1.43, −1.56, −1.64, and −0.11 eV, respectively. Compared with that of filling up the vacancy with O, we found that for CuOCuO/Al2O3 binary system ΔG O (−1.08 eV) > ΔG Cl (−1.43 eV); whereas for CuOCoO/Al2O3 ternary system ΔG O (−3.31 eV) << ΔG Cl (−1.56 eV). It means that for the binary catalyst, O vacancy could not be readily replenished by O2; instead, it tends to be poisoned by Cl owing to its strong adsorption, which could quickly lead to the deactivation of the catalyst (Cu–Cl–Cu site could not continue the reaction). These results are in an excellent agreement with our experiments and Pérez-Ramírez et al.’s results. After adding Co, however, the binding strength of O is significantly strengthened that overwhelms the binding strength of Cl. Therefore, on CuOCoO/Al2O3 surface the vacancy will be predominately occupied by O, Cu–Cl–Co structure will not be formed, thus avoiding the change of surface phase and deactivation. Also for multi-nuclear Co3O4CuO system, ΔG Cl (−0.11 eV) is very minor, thus greatly hinders Cl poisoning. Bader charge difference calculations were further carried out to show electron flow upon the Cl and O adsorption (Fig. S7 and the following note). Looking closely at Table 3, we can notice that Cl2 formation (reaction 7) and water formation (reaction 2) are likely to be the rate-limiting step of the overall reaction due to significant rises on the free energy, which is in good agreement with our previous work [48] and the work of other groups [49,50]. An accurate determination of the rate-limiting step involves the using of kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations [50], which is out of the scope of this study. Here we use ΔG of reaction 2 and 7 as an indicator for the primary trend of the reaction. For OCoOCuO, we notice that the ΔG Cl is greatly smaller than ΔG O, thus this catalyst could be severely poisoned by Cl and loses its reactivity. For CuOCuO and CoOCuO, both of their rate-limiting steps are reaction 2 (water formation) with ΔG of nearly 1 eV. CuOCuO further suffers from Cl poisoning as we mentioned before; its reactivity could also be very low. For CoOCuO, the addition of Co facilitates filling of O vacancies that rules out Cl poisoning, but the O adsorption (reaction 4) is so strong that the surface may reconstruct to OCoCuO. Finally, for Co3O4CuO, both Cl and O adsorption are moderate (reaction 3 and 4), and the former rate-limiting step (reaction 2) is greatly facilitated (ΔG = −0.15 eV), and the rate-limiting step turns to step 7 (Cl desorption, 0.78 eV), the ΔG of which is lower than the water formation on CuOCuO or CoOCuO. Overall, we can conclude that Co3O4CuO could be the most favorable active site for catalyzing Deacon process over Al2O3 (110) with a rate-limiting step of Cl formation and desorption at a free energy rise of 0.78 eV. The adding of Co have greatly hindered Cl poisoning and facilitated water formation. Finally, we can conclude that the benefits of using ternary CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 as catalysts are (i) it is more stable than the CuO/Al2O3 binary system; (ii) the high valence of Co leads to more O incorporated in the catalysts’ surface and reduces the binding of the Cl on the vacant site, thus hinders Cl poisoning; (iii) It facilitates the overall reaction by lowering the ΔG of water formation 4 Conclusions Deacon process is the most intensively investigated and the most widely utilized technique in industry to realize chlorine recovery from HCl. To improve the stability of CuO-based catalysts and increase its overall activity, in this work, we developed CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 catalysts and following results/conclusions are obtained: 1) The CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 we developed delivered unprecedentedly stability with a x HCl of above 80% for at least 1000 h. 2) The XRD, Raman, SEM, HRTEM and H2-TPR characterizations suggested that the addition of Co greatly enhanced the dispersion of CuO on Al2O3 and hindered the reduction of CuO due to their strong interaction. 3) The reaction kinetics results suggested that the catalysts still obeyed the M-K mechanism. The XRD results of used catalysts suggested that the presence of Co greatly inhibited the deep chlorination of the catalysts under reaction atmosphere. 4) DFT calculations proved that the introduced Co will be well mixed up with Cu, making the catalyst surface easier to be oxidized and the chlorination (Cl poisoning) is greatly hindered. In the most stable Co3O4CuO/Al2O3 system, overall reaction is facilitated by lowering the difficulty of the water formation (could be the rate-limiting step). coredata.dc:description: Offering a substantial method to convert HCl to Cl2 over CuCl2/pumice, Deacon process is of great importance in chemical industry. In the process, the difficulty of Cl2 formation/desorption and catalyst re-oxidation have been unanimously recognized as the origin of the instability of CuO-based catalysts. In this work, the stability of the CuO/Al2O3 catalyst was significantly improved by adding Co. The fabricated CuO(12)–CoO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst showed unprecedented stability with HCl conversion (x HCl) above 80%, lasting for at least 1000 h. The X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectra, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) characterizations suggested that the addition of Co greatly enhanced the dispersion of CuO on Al2O3 and hindered the reduction of CuO due to their strong interaction. The results of reaction kinetics suggested that the lattice oxygen participated in the reaction and the reaction order on oxygen was estimated to be 0.15, suggesting that the catalyst obeyed the Mars-van Krevelen (M-K) mechanism, while only small amount of oxygen was required to maintain the activity of catalysts compared to CuO/Al2O3. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations proved that the CuO–CoO x /Al2O3 ternary system was more stable than CuO/Al2O3 binary system and easier to be oxidized by O2, which greatly reduced the difficulty of Cl2 associative desorption.
